name: Landlord Previously Occupied
short_description: Landlord or family member previously occupied as main residence

notice_requirement.timing: Before or at start of tenancy
notice_requirement.content: Notice must state landlord may recover possession under Ground 1
notice_requirement.exception: Court may dispense if just and equitable

current_requirement.need: Requires dwelling as only or principal home

notice_period.court_proceedings: Can be started after notice expires

evidence_required: Proof of prior occupation (utility bills, council tax, electoral roll)
Written notice given at tenancy start
Current requirement for property (e.g., sale of current home, job relocation)

high_probability: Clear written notice at tenancy start
medium_probability: Prior occupation provable but evidence limited
low_probability: No notice given and court refuses to dispense

red_flags: No written notice given at start
Landlord bought property as investment (never lived there)
Tenant is vulnerable and Ground 1 claim appears retaliatory
tenant_defenses: No notice given and no good reason to dispense
Claim is retaliatory (doesn't prevent possession but affects damages)
notes: Ground 1 is MANDATORY - if proved, court MUST grant possession. However, strict notice requirements mean many claims fail on technicality.
case_law: Boyle v Verrall [1997] - Court can dispense with notice requirement if just and equitable
Fernandes v Parvardin [1982] - Prior occupation must be proved on balance of probabilities
